issues.title: Look and feel need improvement for better readability

requests.text: Customer requested a demo on calculator functionality (OOTB formulas)

signal_content:
:new_user: *Lovely Mandal* :new_user:
:customervivo:*Customer Name : Clark County*
:clock2: *Date :* 2025-03-11
:group-people: *Attendees :* <@W4RU4N66R>, <@W012PACNGHJ>, <@U01G51VDXB8>
:loading-2248:*Notes*
• Customer Use case : 
    ◦ Total number of Forms : 20 
    ◦ Future use case: Clark County has PDF forms and would like to migrate to web-based forms.
    ◦ Customer would like to explore AEM form capabilities 
    ◦ Most of the forms are Contact us Forms 
    ◦ Forms are capturing data through Email 
    ◦ Traffic*:* ~1,000 forms per month across all forms (may increase).
    ◦ Need*:* Store data in a digitized format for future reference.
    ◦ Accessibility Standards: WCAG 2.1 
        ▪︎ QA in a later phase will ensure readability through screen readers.
        ▪︎ Look and feel need improvement for better readability.
        ▪︎ Styling should be standardized across the entire website.
        ▪︎ Minimize developer effort.
    ◦ Rules : OOTB rules for calculations 
    ◦ Rules : Sending the email to a particular group based on drop-down selection 
    ◦ Form Submitter, gets a Submission confirmation message. (No email)
    ◦ Rule : Add links based on the drop -down selection. Ex: getting a marriage License. Provide a link which can, help navigate people where they need to go.
    ◦ Form updates: Fairly static; may require annual updates.
• Suggestions made by Adobe :
    ◦ Store info in Spreadsheets 
    ◦ Suggested other submit actions as well
    ◦ Using score based reCAPTCHA (invisible)
    ◦ Form Submission ROI and Conversion improvement - Customer is interested in exploring this use case
        ▪︎ Use case : user can come back and fill the form from where they have left 
• As of now, customer does not capture data of number of submissions. Would like to explore this option in AEM as well
        ▪︎   
Demos & Discussions by Adobe
1. Document-Based Approach
    ◦ Explained spreadsheet-based form storage.
    ◦ Demoed form properties, fields, publishing, and rule configurations.
    ◦ Submission: Explained submit-to-email method.
    ◦ Customer requested a demo on calculator functionality (OOTB formulas).
2. WYSIWYG (Universal Editor) Approach
    ◦ Introduced Adaptive Forms & Data Submission Actions.
    ◦ Briefly covered Universal Editor UI, built-in components, and styling options.
    ◦ Demoed: 
        ▪︎ Rule Editor & form publishing (secure bank use case).
        ▪︎ Column structures & custom component creation.
        ▪︎ AI Assistant in form creation.
    ◦ Mentioned Power Automate for workflow automation.

:todo_done: *Next Action*
• Customer Action Item : 
    ◦ To provide us with an email body template in which they need to send the form data.
    ◦  
• Adobe Action Item : 
    ◦ Arrange for another meeting to show case AEM capabilities like Submit actions, Data source, power Automate flow, capturing form conversion (ROI)

issues.title: Performance issues with large forms
Need for code editor in core component development
Lack of support for XML schema in core components

requests.text: Interested in JSON support in Designer
Interested in Success Studio and GenAI capabilities

signal_content:
:new_user: *Sudhanshu Singh* :new_user:
:customervivo:*Customer Name : IRS W&I Media & Publications*
:clock2: *Date :* 2025-03-18
:group-people: *Attendees :* <@W4XTCQ07J>, <@U02RMEY3D1C>
:loading-2248:*Notes*
_[Generated by AI]_ Meeting notes:
*Key points:* They have around *100 forms to be created* (from PDF, and move existing AFv1 to AFv2), and they are on *on-prem Gov Cloud*. Performance is critical and open to evaluate React based rendition on a React page as well. Were happy to know about Review component, and Table not as critical as Review - and currently PDF forms used for Review as well. Interested in *Success Studio*, and *GenAI* capabilities (though I highlighted that some of the new innovations could not be available on on-prem). They want *JSON support in Designer*!
*Participants from IRS side:* *Vara Prasada Rao Ande* (Publishing Program Specialist, Digital Mobile & Adaptive Forms), *Terry James P* (Form Specialist - most probably.. He is working on one of the complex forms)*, Manno Steven R* (IRS leadership)

• *Adobe Support Call:* Ande explained the purpose of the call, which is to discuss Adobe tickets and seek help from the Adobe Engineering team to convert existing adaptive forms to foundational components using a utility tool.
    ◦ *Purpose of Call:* Ande explained that the call was initiated to discuss Adobe tickets and seek assistance from the Adobe Engineering team to convert existing adaptive forms to foundational components using a utility tool. The goal is to reduce the effort required for the conversion and implement best practices suggested by the Adobe team.
    ◦ *Adobe Tickets:* Ande mentioned that several Adobe tickets were submitted, and the Adobe Support team recommended a call with the Adobe Engineering team to discuss tools and utilities for converting existing adaptive forms to foundational components.
    ◦ *Utility Tool:* Ande highlighted the utility tool provided by Adobe, which can help automatically convert foundational component forms into core component forms, reducing the manual effort involved in the conversion process.
    ◦ *Support and Best Practices:* The intention of the call is to get support from the Adobe Engineering team to reduce project effort and implement best practices for the conversion process.
• *Migration Tool Demo:* Sudhanshu mentioned that they do not have the migration tool handy but can schedule a subsequent call to demo the tool and explain its support for migration.
    ◦ *Tool Availability:* Sudhanshu stated that the migration tool is not currently available for demonstration but offered to schedule a subsequent call to demo the tool and explain its support for migration.
    ◦ *Migration Support:* Sudhanshu explained that the migration tool supports the migration of the structure, easing the migration effort by providing initial content that can be modified for business logic.
• *Current vs. Future Development:* Ande presented the current and future development process for adaptive forms, highlighting the challenges with core components and the decision to leverage the latest features of core components.
    ◦ *Current Development:* Ande described the current development process, which involves creating adaptive forms using foundational components and XML schema for form submission.
    ◦ *Future Development:* Ande outlined the future development process, which aims to use core components and JSON schema for form submission to leverage the latest features and improve performance.
    ◦ *Challenges:* Ande highlighted the challenges faced with core components, including the lack of support for XML schema and the need to create both JSON and XML schemas, which adds complexity and effort to the development process.
    ◦ *Decision to Leverage Core Components:* The decision to leverage core components was made to take advantage of the latest features and recommendations from Adobe, despite the challenges involved in the transition.
• *Form Submission Formats:* Sudhanshu and Ande discussed the use of JSON and XML formats for form submission, with Sudhanshu recommending JSON for better performance and reduced dependencies.
    ◦ *JSON vs. XML:* Sudhanshu recommended using JSON for form submission due to its better performance and reduced dependencies compared to XML.
    ◦ *Current Use of XML:* Ande explained that the current process involves using XML schema for form submission, but they have recently started using JSON for new requirements from external systems.
    ◦ *Performance Benefits:* Sudhanshu highlighted the performance benefits of using JSON, including improved client-side performance and reduced dependencies on third-party libraries like jQuery.
    ◦ *Future Development with JSON:* Ande expressed the need for Adobe Engineering team support to enable JSON schema binding in the designer level to avoid the additional effort of maintaining both JSON and XML schemas.
• *Large Forms Performance:* Terry emphasized the need for better performance in large forms and expressed interest in using core components and JSON submission to achieve this.
    ◦ *Performance Issues:* Terry emphasized the poor performance of large forms created with foundational components and the need for better performance.
    ◦ *Core Components:* Terry expressed interest in using core components and JSON submission to improve the performance of large forms.
    ◦ *Lightweight Forms:* Terry highlighted the importance of creating lightweight forms with core components to ensure a faster and more efficient user experience.
    ◦ *Performance Measurement:* Terry mentioned the need to measure the performance benefits of using core components and JSON submission for large forms.
• *Review Component:* Terry highlighted the importance of the review component for their forms, and Sudhanshu confirmed that it will be available soon.
    ◦ *Importance of Review Component:* Terry emphasized the critical need for a review component in their forms, which allows users to review their submissions before finalizing.
    ◦ *Availability:* Sudhanshu confirmed that the review component will be available soon and provided details on its functionality, including the ability to review different panels and selectively choose components to review.
• *Code Editor Challenges:* Ande raised concerns about the lack of a code editor for core component development, and Sudhanshu explained the rationale behind its removal and potential solutions.
    ◦ *Concerns Raised:* Ande raised concerns about the lack of a code editor for core component development, which creates a strong dependency on the development team for writing custom functions.
    ◦ *Rationale for Removal:* Sudhanshu explained that the code editor was removed to maintain a separation of phases and personas, with developers working in a Git repository for better source control and tracking changes.
    ◦ *Potential Solutions:* Sudhanshu mentioned that on the cloud service, there is an option to store custom functions in a Git repository, which can be reviewed and made available in the visual rule editor without triggering a pipeline. He offered to check the feasibility of supporting this on the 6.5 setup.
• *Table Component:* Ande and Sudhanshu discussed the need for a table component in core components, with Sudhanshu suggesting potential improvements and customer-driven development.
    ◦ *Need for Table Component:* Ande highlighted the need for a table component in core components, which is currently available in foundational components but missing in core components.
    ◦ *Potential Improvements:* Sudhanshu suggested potential improvements, such as using responsive layouts like accordions instead of tables for better mobile device compatibility.
    ◦ *Customer-Driven Development:* Sudhanshu mentioned that the development of new components and improvements is customer-driven, and they are open to including critical requirements in their roadmap based on customer feedback.
• *XML Schema Support:* Ande inquired about the support for XML schema in core components, and Sudhanshu confirmed that it is not currently supported and not in the immediate roadmap.
    ◦ *Inquiry on XML Schema:* Ande inquired about the support for XML schema in core components, expressing the need to avoid the additional effort of maintaining both JSON and XML schemas.
    ◦ *Current Support:* Sudhanshu confirmed that XML schema support is not currently available in core components and is not in the immediate roadmap.
    ◦ *Future Plans:* Sudhanshu mentioned that they might revisit the requirement in the second half of the year if it becomes a critical requirement for customers.
• *Migration Utility:* Sudhanshu shared links to the migration utility for converting foundation forms to core components and converting XFA forms to adaptive forms, and suggested a follow-up session for a demo.
    ◦ *Shared Links:* Sudhanshu shared links to the migration utility for converting foundation forms to core components and converting XFA forms to adaptive forms.
    ◦ *Follow-Up Session:* Sudhanshu suggested scheduling a follow-up session to demo the migration utility and provide further assistance with the conversion process _*(AFv1 to AFV2 and AFCS) -* cc:  <@U03BKR6K3R8>_ _<@U0213T59LMN>_ 
:todo_done: *Next Action*
• *Migration Tool Demo:* Schedule a subsequent call to demo the migration tool and walk through the support available in the tool. (Sudhanshu)
• *PPT Review:* Share the draft PPT with 7 slides and go through it during the meeting. (Ande)
• *Form Conversion:* Share the complex form with the Adobe Engineering team for conversion and performance evaluation. (Ande, JP)
• *XML and JSON Schema Support:* Follow up on enabling JSON schema support at the designer level to avoid using XML schema for new forms. (Sudhanshu)
• *Documentation Sharing:* Share documentation and recordings related to the review component and other relevant features with the tea

:clock2: *Date :* 2025-03-20
:group-people: *Attendees :* <@WE163TH43>
:loading-2248:*Notes*
*Discussion Summary*
*Issues with the Editor:*
1. *Fragment Width*: The fragment does not have the correct width when dropped on the canvas during document creation. This issue arises when the fragment is created outside of a subform.
2. *PDF Preview*: The PDF preview is not functioning correctly when a fragment is present in the document.
3. *MasterPage Option*: The masterPage option in the editor is causing confusion for customers and needs to be hidden.
*New Features Requested for Demo to their Business Unit:*
1. *FDM Use Case with filtered data*: NFCU requires a use case for data fetching using filters or any hooks that they can implement independently. An approach needs to be provided.
2. *Permission Management*: NFCU needs the ability to grant permissions to groups or users to edit communications.
*Non-Editor Use Case:*
• NFCU needs to know if there is a transformer available to convert an HTML table to an XDP table.
:todo_done: *Next Action*
• Action Items
1. *Fix PDF Preview and Fragment Width Issues*:
    ◦ *PDF Preview*: Resolve the issue where the PDF preview is not functioning correctly when a fragment is present in the document.
    ◦ *Fragment Width*: Address the problem where the fragment does not have the correct width when dropped on the canvas during document creation.
2. *Provide Details for PDF Preview with Filtered Data*:
    ◦ Ensure that the PDF preview using filtered data, allowing users to see the relevant information in the preview.

:clock2: *Date :* 2025-03-21
:group-people: *Attendees :* <@U0213T59LMN>, <@U03N27GAZDZ>
:loading-2248:*Notes*
*Discussion Agenda: New OOTB Marketo Connector*
• Brad from the Spark NZ team highlighted a few minor issues and suggestions, including improvements to the Marketo Cloud Configuration screen and ensuring the data source properties in the Adaptive Forms editor are listed alphabetically.
• They currently have existing Marketo forms with smart lists and campaigns configured based on the “Marketo Form Fill” activity.
• We explained that we are implementing an OOTB custom “Form Fill” activity similar to the Marketo Form Fill activity, allowing them to transition their campaigns and smart lists to this new custom activity.
• Their smart lists in Marketo use the *Marketo assetId (form ID)* to segregate data. We suggested achieving the same functionality by creating a custom field in Marketo and populating it using a hidden field in Adaptive Forms.
• They raised an issue where fields coming from SFDC were not visible in our data source tree. We need to investigate this further.
• Brad acknowledged that the new OOTB integration is excellent and very easy to implement.
• They tentatively plan to go live with their first form by the end of May.
• Lastly, our *GenAI assistant* was briefly discussed. A follow-up meeting is scheduled for next week to discuss *AI-powered forms, the Universal Editor, and headless forms*.

:todo_done: *Next Action*
• Need to provide timelines for enhancement in OOTB Marketo connector for implementing Form Fill Custom Activity and other issues.

requests.text: Need to identify and share a plan on how we can avoid hotfixes in future, ensuring that all the hotfixes are included in the next service pack.
Automation plan to avoid regression in this area.

signal_content:
:new_user: *Sudhanshu Singh* :new_user:
:customervivo:*Customer Name : IRS (Internal meeting)*
:clock2: *Date :* 2025-03-25
:group-people: *Attendees :* <@W4XTCQ07J>, <@W5MFNAZ63>, <@WPJSSF62C>
:loading-2248:*Notes*
*Internal sync-up for concerns raised by IRS regarding multiple hotfixes delivered, and how we could avoid hotfix.*

*Issue:*
• The IRS features/support have a special requirement to introduce sling mapping - which was validated manually (complexity in automation/bandwidth) - since initially no other customer requested for this. But recently there are other customers using it.
    ◦ The feature was delivered as a hotfix on SP21 - but later when merging to SP22 - a regression was identified for other customers and had to be reverted - and IRS had to be given a hotfix again.
    ◦ In SP23 - this was introduced with an updated fix, and validated manually, but was broken (regression) to an invalid merge conflict resolution, and thus required an updated hotfix again.
:todo_done: *Next Action*
• Need to identify and share a plan on how we can avoid hotfixes in future - ensuring that all the hotfixes and included in next service pack.
• Automation plan - to avoid regression in this area.

signal_content:
:new_user: *Navneet Agarwal* :new_user:
:customervivo:*Customer Name : Spark NZ*
:clock2: *Date :* 2025-03-27
:group-people: *Attendees :* <@U0213T59LMN>, <@WLWHN4TV3>, <@W4R5M9P4H>
:loading-2248:*Notes*
• The team presented the GenAI capabilities in forms manager, core components form editor and Universal editor. Features demonstrated:
    ◦ Figma to AF (FM)
    ◦ User query to AF (FM)
    ◦ Add panel using user query (CC editor)
    ◦ Create rule (UE/CC editor)
    ◦ Update Layout (CC editor)
    ◦ Configure submit (CC editor)
    ◦ Create form/panel using attachment (UE)
    ◦ Add/delete/update fields (UE)
    ◦ Update layout, move components (UE)
• They use a lot of Figma designs to create the forms so the customer was willing to use this for their use cases.
• The capabilities demonstrated can really help them reduce the time for authoring of a form as there are often last minute changes on the form.
• They also mentioned, their designer can also use this for rapid prototyping.
• They had a couple of questions around :
    ◦ Can you give PDFs as attachment for creating form in assistant?  (Not supported as of now)
    ◦ Do you need the figma design to be publicly accessible or is there some authentication token we can provide ? (Need to document this before giving them)
    ◦ They have custom components which they would like to use when form is getting created. (Need to check internally how we can support this)
• We also asked them in what other areas we can help them using the generative AI for example generating test cases etc. 
• They also mentioned the E2E testing has always been a pain point for them.
• They will be enabling EDS in their next fiscal year which will be in July’25, until then they want the support for Assistant in CC Forms editor.
• Rishi also answered their queries about headless and demonstrated the code sandbox that we have for headless components.
• Based on their use-case they can explore to use react-native for rendering the headless.
:todo_done: *Next Action*
• Enabling AI Assistant for the customer.
• Customer to come back with env details where this needs to be enabled.
• Customer to discuss internally and come back with what other areas do they think GenAi can help them.

issues.title: High manual effort in printing, filling, and validating forms
Difficulty in scaling and loading large HTML5 forms
Dispatcher caching is not effective for HTML5 forms

signal_content:
:new_user: *Vijay Kumar Jalagari* :new_user:
:customervivo:*Customer Name : Charles Schwab*
:clock2: *Date :* 2025-03-18
:group-people: *Attendees :* <@W6CBB4953>, <@W4R4S9FS4>, <@W5HEU5M7Y>, <@W4RU4N66R>
:loading-2248:*Notes*
*Forms License:* *Yes, On-prem*
*Primary Use Case:* HTML 5 Forms.
*Adobe Products in Use:* DAM & Ultimate Success
*Attendees:* Michaell (Platform Manager), George (Platform Manager), Abhishek (SME), Dennis (Manager) and Stephane (Technical Lead)

*Current State:*
• Customer is currently using *XDP-based PDF forms*, with over *800+ forms* and associated *fragments*. 
• These PDFs are *printed and manually filled* by users. A *third-party vendor* reviews, validates, and contacts customers for any corrections. 
• Some forms span up to *30 pages*, adding complexity and validation effort. 
*Key Challenges:*

• High manual effort in printing, filling, and validating forms. 
• Difficulty in *scaling and loading large HTML5 forms* (converted from XDP), particularly those with high page counts. 
• *Dispatcher caching is not effective* for these HTML5 forms, impacting performance. 
*Key Use Cases & Goals:*

• The customer aims to *reduce 90% of paper and manual validation costs* incurred via vendor processing. 
*Planned Approach (Phase-wise):*

*Phase 1:*

• Convert XDP to *HTML5* forms. 
• Implement *client-side validation* to reduce dependency on manual vendor review. 
• Currently in PoC phase but facing performance/scalability issues. 
*Phase 2:*

• Add *prefill capability* using internal databases without query parameters (to avoid disclosure of information) 
• *Integrate with Adobe Sign* for digital signatures. 

*Adobe Recommendation:*

• Migrate to *Adobe Cloud or AMS* to resolve *scaling and caching issues*, especially for large forms. 

:todo_done: *Next Action*
Customer to *share sample PDFs* and *schedule a follow-up meeting* to review issues observed in HTML5 form rendering and performance.

:new_user: *Vijay Kumar Jalagari* :new_user:
:customervivo:*Customer Name : Abbvie*
:clock2: *Date :* 2025-03-19
:group-people: *Attendees :* <@W6CBB4953>, <@W4R4S9FS4>, <@W5HEU5M7Y>, <@W4RU4N66R>
:loading-2248:*Notes*
*Forms License:* *Yes, On-prem to Cloud*
*Primary Use Case:* Adaptive Forms.
*Adobe Products in Use:* Sites & Assets
*Attendees:* Joe George (Director), Shivendra Vikram Singh (Platform Manager), Sudhakar Vudatha

• The customer has *finalized plans to start migration work from next week (last week of March)*. 
• They have selected *Cognizant as the implementation partner*, who will work under the *guidance of Ajila*. 
• In addition to the current scope, they have a few more *commerce websites* where *form data needs to be submitted to Salesforce*. 
• Another team within *AbbVie* (likely *Botox* or a related department) has a use case involving *data hydration into AEP*. This data is then used for *audience creation* to support *prospecting patient journeys*. 

:todo_done: *Next Action*

issues.title: Multi-step process for communication generation and delivery

requests.text: Review the existing architecture and explore ways to reduce the time required for generating and sending communications

signal_content:
:new_user: *Vijay Kumar Jalagari* :new_user:
:customervivo:*Customer Name : LPL*
:clock2: *Date :* 2025-03-19
:group-people: *Attendees :* <@W6CBB4953>, <@W4R4S9FS4>, <@W5HEU5M7Y>, <@W4RU4N66R>
:loading-2248:*Notes*
*Forms License:* *Yes,  Cloud*
*Primary Use Case:* Regulated Communication & Adaptive Forms.
*Adobe Products in Use:* Sites & Assets
*Attendees:* Betsy (VP), Naveen Sharma (Manager)


*Current State:*

• Customer has *250+ XDP-based forms* in use. 
• They have an *in-house system* that triggers the account creation process on capturing some form fields and persists data in a *PostgreSQL database*. 
• The system exposes data via *JSON APIs*. 
• They use case is to generate and deliver approximately *2,500 communications per day*, referred to as “envelopes.” 
*Use Case:*

• They aim to build communications and send them for signing. 
• The current vendor (likely *ACS*) has implemented a *multi-API or multi step process*: 
• JSON → XML → Generate PDF → Create Agreement → Send for Signature 
• The customer would like us to *review the existing architecture* and explore ways to *reduce the time required for generating and sending communications*. 
*Future Interest:*

• After improving the communication flow, they are also considering *replacing their current in-house data capture system* with *Adaptive Forms*. 

:todo_done: *Next Action*
• *Include the customer in the VIP program*. 
• *Review the current architecture* and identify optimisation opportunities. 
• *Define a successful path* toward improving communication generation and exploring Adaptive Forms adoption.

Next Action
• The customer will share a sample form. 
• The Adobe team will demonstrate how AEM Forms supports their end-to-end requirements and capabilities.

In 2023, *FCSA invested in AEM Forms as a Cloud Service*. While they have not yet gone live with any forms, the initial focus was on migrating their *external websites to Adobe*. Now, they are ready to *explore use cases and AEM Forms capabilities* in more depth.

*Key Use Cases:*

• Support for both *marketing and business forms*, including *workflow integration* 
• Ability to build *multi-step forms* 
• Prefill forms using APIs 
• Interactive chart components within forms 
• Integration with Adobe Analytics and sending mail notifications, on form submission  
• Interest in *experimentation* and *headless form capabilities*, especially for integration with *Flutter-based mobile applications* 
• Prefilling forms using *Documents*

issues.title: Scalability concern with current implementation
Hesitant to replace the BPM tool for data capturing

requests.text: Review current implementation and suggest best way to implement it in AEM Forms

signal_content:
:new_user: *Darshan Mahor* :new_user:
:customervivo:*Customer Name : LPL Financial*
:clock2: *Date :* 2025-04-02
:group-people: *Attendees :* <@W9QMZFR39>, <@W4RSW3ECC>, <@W4R5LUPK3>, <@W5HEU5M7Y>, <@W4R4S9FS4>, <@W010NNJV7S8>
:loading-2248:*Notes*
*Current Document Generation flow*
• The customer fetches JSON data from a web service (BPM tool used for account creation, which extracts form field data and persists it in a database).
• JSON is transformed into XML through a two-step process:
    ◦ Converting camel case JSON to XML.
    ◦ Applying XSLT transformation to generate the final XML.
• The latest template is fetched using custom code.
• The generated XML and template are sent to the Generate PDF API.
*Requirement and Concern:*
• Customer wants us to review their current implementation and want us to share best way we can implement it in AEM Forms. Customer major concern is to make system more scalable.
• Hesitant to replace the BPM tool that they use data for data capturing.
• Customer also keep the mapping for every form field with Json field per Form. They need to keep it as both the schemas i.e., Json schema and schema that they use in template is different. 
• They have few older Forms also that they want to migrate to AEM Forms. We tried to get information about how much time it takes to them migrate 1 Form but they don't have this data available.
:todo_done: *Next Action*
• The customer will share collaterals i.e.,  sample XDPs, transformation code, existing forms from their other system, and the JSON schema, after receiving approval for sharing code and samples.
• Once we receive the collaterals, we need to evaluate them to enhance the scalability of their current approach.

requests.text: Create a workflow model that accurately implements the author’s decision-making process based on submitted data.
Explain the pros and cons of migrating forms to the cloud.
Explain the storage and management of attached documents on the cloud.
Maintain the same look and feel for forms used by executives.

signal_content:
:new_user: *Sakshat Chahal* :new_user:
:customervivo:*Customer Name : Cintas*
:clock2: *Date :* 2025-04-02
:group-people: *Attendees :* <@U0213T59LMN>, <@W4RU4N66R>, <@W010NNJV7S8>, <@W4RU5J3JR>, <@U05DURMMBGV>, <@WALHLA4PP>
:loading-2248:*Notes*
Customer's Requirements:

The customer shared an automation process flow for their Policy Exception (PE) form, outlining the steps involved when a submitter submits a form. They wanted us to create a workflow model that would accurately implement the author’s decision-making process based on the submitted data.

Meeting Notes:
Model presentation: We demonstrated the custom workflow model  explaining the different pathways for approving, rejecting, or deferring the submitted form by showing how the workflow iterates through the list of approvers to assign it to different approvers.

Theming: Cintas's team also inquired about the look and feel of the forms when moving to the cloud. We explained that the authoring UI would be modernized, but the form's appearance could be customized based on branding requirements. They also discussed the possibility of reusing existing themes.

Form Migration and Maintenance: Their another ask was about the pros and cons of migrating forms to the cloud. It was explained that migrating forms would allow leveraging new capabilities like headless and generative UI, but there would be some manual effort required to recreate themes.

Document Storage and Management: They also enquired about the storage and management of attached documents on the cloud. It was explained that AEM forms do not persist any data, and the documents would need to be configured to go to the system of record. They also mentioned the possibility of using external data sources.

Form Customisation: Finally, they asked about maintaining the same look and feel for forms used by executives. They were assured that the forms could be customised to match the existing appearance, but some manual effort would be required.
:todo_done: *Next Action*
• Model Validation: Cintas's representative in the meeting would share the Workflow model with other team members for validation and testing.
• Form Look and Feel(on call): Vijay has already shared the published URL of an Adaptive Form built on Cloud using a custom theme to showcase the look and feel of forms on the cloud.
• Their representative also suggested to schedule another call if they encounter any more concerns and questions.
